Sustainability Frameworks and Methodologies: Various frameworks have been proposed to assess or improve research software longevity. . Such models help gauge a project’s stage in its lifecycle and what is needed for it to mature sustainably. . In other words, when project-specific software isn’t preserved or maintained, subsequent scholars may struggle to validate or build upon that research. In summary, prior research confirms the importance of software sustainability and offers partial frameworks (multi-dimensional criteria, archiving protocols, etc.)​

Longevity and Sustainability of Research Software in Historical Studies: A Literature Review


1. Overview of the Field


Research software has become indispensable in historical studies – from digital humanities and archaeology to historical linguistics and corpus/textual analysis – yet ensuring the longevity and sustainability of these tools remains a pressing challenge. Research software in this context refers to custom or adapted programs, scripts, and digital tools developed to assist scholarly research. Studies across domains consistently report that such software is often ephemeral, frequently disappearing or becoming unusable within a few years of creationblog.f1000.comlive-digital-humanities-berkeley.pantheon.berkeley.edu. For example, one longitudinal study found that over 80% of scientific datasets (and by extension many associated software) were inaccessible after two decades, highlighting the fragility of digital research outputsfrogheart.ca. In the humanities, numerous digital projects and tools from the 1990s and 2000s have “faded away,” no longer functional due to obsolete dependencies or defunct websiteshal.science. This transience is not merely a technical concern; it undermines the scholarly record, reproducibility, and cumulative knowledge-building in historical research.


Key challenges affecting software longevity in historical studies are multifaceted. Technical challenges include software rot and obsolescence: as underlying operating systems, programming languages, and libraries evolve, older research software can break or become incompatiblelive-digital-humanities-berkeley.pantheon.berkeley.edu. Many digital humanities projects rely on complex stacks (databases, web frameworks, etc.), which, if not meticulously maintained, will eventually fail due to security updates or API changes. Institutional and financial challenges are equally significant. Unlike commercial software backed by companies, academic research software is typically developed under time-limited grants with little provision for post-project maintenance. Once the initial funding ends, there may be no resources or dedicated personnel to continue updating the tool. Surveys have found that academic incentive structures provide few rewards for maintaining software (as compared to publishing papers), leading to a “project mentality” where tools are abandoned after fulfilling immediate research goalssemanticscholar.org. Indeed, the lack of career recognition for research software engineers (RSEs) and developers in academia has been identified as a barrier to sustainabilitysemanticscholar.org. In historical studies, this challenge is pronounced: many projects have relied on graduate students or contract programmers whose expertise (and personal commitment to the software) departs when they dohal.science. Human factors thus play a pivotal role – loss of key knowledge holders, inadequate documentation, and turnover all contribute to software attrition.


Another challenge is the relatively small user base for many humanities software tools. A piece of archaeological analysis software or a specialized linguistic corpus tool might be used by only a handful of research groups. With such limited communities, it is difficult to mobilize ongoing support or crowdsourced contributions, in contrast to some scientific software (e.g. astronomical or bioinformatics tools) that have thousands of users and contributors. Moreover, historical data and methods can be highly specialized, which sometimes leads developers to craft “one-off” bespoke solutions; these may lack the generality or modularity that encourages reuse beyond the original context. Interdisciplinary differences also emerge: fields like computational physics or astronomy have a longer tradition of building shared, long-lived software (some codes are maintained over decades), whereas digital history and archaeology only began intensive software development more recently, often with a focus on prototype projects and proof-of-concept experiments. Consequently, historians are now grappling with challenges long familiar in other domainsacademic.oup.comsemanticscholar.org. There is growing recognition in the historical research community that, much as with data curation, software stewardship is vital for the field’s intellectual legacy. This has led scholars to seek lessons from other disciplines and from the commercial sector on how to prolong the life of essential research tools.


Notably, the challenges in historical studies parallel those observed across science and engineering fields, albeit with some differences of emphasis. In scientific computing, studies have found that a substantial fraction of research code is never publicly released or preserved. For instance, a recent empirical study of economics and social-science articles (using the German SOEP panel data) found that only ~6% of studies provided replication code at the time of publicationdiw.de. Even though this rate has improved in recent years (due to journals’ replication policies), it underscores how historically much research software was not readily accessible or sustained. In the domain of computational social science, Janssen (2017) reviewed 2,367 agent-based modeling papers (1990–2014) and found only about 10% mentioned available model code, with many links over time becoming invalidjasss.org. These figures resonate with anecdotes in historical research: scholars often recall projects where code was lost on a student’s computer or websites that went offline shortly after a project’s end. Such common patterns suggest that the software lifecycle in academia tends toward brief “one-and-done” usage unless specific interventions are made. The remainder of this review examines those interventions and strategies – both conceptual frameworks and practical measures – that have been proposed or tried in order to extend the useful life of research software in historical studies and beyond.


2. Existing Frameworks and Methodologies


Efforts to address research software sustainability have produced a number of frameworks, principles, and methodologies which can guide project design and institutional policy. A central theme in these frameworks is treating software as a valuable research output in its own right, akin to data or publications, that merits curation and planning for longevity. One influential set of guidelines is the FAIR principles – originally developed for data management – which emphasize making digital assets Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable. These have recently been explicitly extended to research software (the FAIR4RS Principles). In 2022, a multi-stakeholder working group published the FAIR for Research Software principles, adapting FAIR’s concepts to the context of softwaresoftware.ac.uk. For example, FAIR4RS recommends rich metadata and persistent identifiers for software (to ensure findability), open licensing and archival in trustworthy repositories (to ensure accessibility), use of widely-adopted standards for inputs/outputs (interoperability), and documentation of code and APIs to foster reuse. Embracing FAIR in historical research software could mean, for instance, assigning DOIs to software releases, describing tools in catalogues like the Digital Humanities Tool Registry, and adhering to data formats that are standard in the field (such as TEI-XML for text data or CIDOC-CRM for heritage data) to maximize interoperability. While FAIR does not in itself guarantee longevity, it lays foundational best practices that make it easier to sustain and migrate software – a tool that is well-documented, open, and standard-compliant is far more likely to be preserved or taken up by others, even if the original team disbandsgithub.comdanielskatz.org.


Another approach is developing software maturity models and assessment frameworks specific to research projects. One recent example is the Research Software Project Maturity Model (RSMM), which provides a structured way to evaluate a project’s sustainability readiness. RSMM defines a set of best practices (on the order of 70+ items) across multiple dimensions – such as documentation, testing, community engagement, governance, and planning – and assigns maturity levels based on adherencesemanticscholar.org. The idea is similar to industry’s CMMI (Capability Maturity Model Integration) but tailored to academic contexts: a project at the highest maturity level would, for instance, have version control and continuous integration in place, clear contributor guidelines, a governance model for decision-making, and a long-term roadmap, whereas a low-maturity project might rely on ad-hoc development by a single person with minimal documentation. Such frameworks help principal investigators and digital humanities labs benchmark their software practices and identify weaknesses (e.g., “bus factor” risks where too much knowledge is held by one individual). The UK’s Software Sustainability Institute (SSI) has advocated a simplified sustainability evaluation built around three core elements – openness, reusability, and maintainability – as a way to gauge project healthtoolstechniques.pbworks.com. Applying these criteria in historical projects can flag, for example, if a digital archaeology tool uses proprietary data formats (low openness), or if a history text-analysis script lacks any tests or documentation (low maintainability). By adopting maturity models early, project teams in the humanities can design software with longevity in mind, rather than treating sustainability as an afterthought.


There are also national and institutional reports that have set out methodologies for sustaining research software. In the Netherlands, a 2021 task force issued comprehensive Recommendations for Research Software Sustainability, which cover topics from software archiving (ensuring source code is deposited in long-term archives like Zenodo or institutional repositories) to continuous funding models (integrating software maintenance into funding schemes)dans.knaw.nlresearchgate.net. Such reports often stress a lifecycle perspective: planning for eventual hand-off of software, defining an end-of-life strategy, and budgeting for maintenance beyond the initial development phase. Funding agencies in some countries are beginning to require Software Management Plans (analogous to Data Management Plans). For example, the UK Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) now asks applicants to outline how project outcomes – including software – will be preserved or handed over at project’s end. Although still not as common as data plans, the inclusion of software sustainability criteria in grant evaluation is a significant methodological shift, aligning incentives with longevity.


In practice, several case studies in digital humanities illustrate both the application of such frameworks and the challenges encountered. A notable case is the Perseus Digital Library, a flagship digital classics project initiated in the 1980s. Perseus has survived through decades by continuously migrating its software and data through different technologies – from HyperCard to bespoke Java and now to more modular architectures – all while maintaining compatibility with earlier data. The project’s leaders embraced standards (TEI for texts), released data openly, and cultivated a user community that advocated for Perseus to receive ongoing institutional support. This aligns with many principles later encapsulated by FAIR and others, even though Perseus predated them. Conversely, Project Bamboo (circa 2008–2012), an ambitious attempt to create a pan-disciplinary cyberinfrastructure for the humanities, is often cited as a cautionary tale. Despite substantial initial funding, Bamboo failed to solidify a sustainable software deliverable, partly due to lack of clear focus and community buy-in. Analyses of Bamboo’s outcome emphasize the importance of community-driven development and iterative, use-case based design – essentially, that sustainability is not just a technical issue but one of meeting actual user needs so that a project remains relevant and garners support.


Frameworks like WSSSPE’s guides (Workshop on Sustainable Software for Science and Engineering) have also been applied or discussed in humanities contexts. The WSSSPE workshops (2013–2018) produced a series of recommendations – e.g., invest in onboarding new contributors, diversify funding sources, develop mentor networks for software – which are broadly applicablearxiv.orgscholar.google.co.nz. Digital humanities centers have begun to adapt these ideas, setting up mechanisms for student developers to transition projects to new teams, or establishing collaborations with library digital preservation units. For instance, the Liberal Arts Collaborative for Digital Innovation (LACOL) has piloted a “software deposit” program where completed student/faculty projects are archived in a central repository with Docker images and metadata, enabling future reuse even if active development ceases. While such frameworks and methodologies are increasingly recognized, their adoption in historical studies is uneven. Some well-resourced projects follow best practices from the start, but many smaller projects remain essentially artisanal, relying on the heroic efforts of individual scholars. The gap between ideal recommendations and on-the-ground practice is therefore an important theme, which we return to in Section 5 (Gaps and Future Work).


3. Empirical Evidence and Case Studies


Empirical studies on research software longevity offer a data-driven perspective on how long software persists and what factors correlate with sustainability. Until recently, much discussion in historical studies was anecdotal, but now a growing body of quantitative and qualitative research sheds light on software lifecycles across disciplines. Repository mining – analyzing platforms like GitHub or Bitbucket – has been a key method to gather evidence. For example, Ait et al. (2022) conducted a large-scale analysis of GitHub repositories to determine the survival rate of open-source projects. They found that a significant proportion of new projects have very short lifespans: many are abandoned or become inactive within the first two yearssemanticscholar.org. Although that study looked at general open-source projects, its findings resonate in academia: many research code repositories (especially those tied to one-off papers) show a burst of initial activity followed by long inactivity. This pattern was confirmed by Russell et al. (2018), who tracked code repositories associated with publications and observed a sharp drop-off in commits after the publication date, suggesting that once the immediate research need is over, maintenance largely stops. Such evidence quantitatively underscores the common scenario where a doctoral student writes software for a dissertation, uploads the code (perhaps to GitHub or as supplemental material), and then no further updates occur after graduation.


Other studies use link decay and archival techniques to measure longevity. In one compelling cross-domain study, Collberg et al. (2016) attempted to reproduce results from 601 computer systems papers by obtaining and running the authors’ softwarewww-dyliss.irisa.frhal.science. They reported extremely low success rates: in a majority of cases the code was unavailable or would not compile/run in a contemporary environmentresearchgate.net. Although focusing on computer science, their methodology – contacting authors, checking websites, using the Internet Archive to find disappeared downloads – is very relevant to historical scholarship. A similar approach in the humanities might involve selecting a set of digital history projects from 2000–2010 and seeing how many are still accessible and functional today. While a comprehensive “reproducibility audit” of historical research software has not yet been published, smaller case studies hint at sobering outcomes. For instance, an informal survey of archaeology GIS plugins presented at a 2019 workshop found that about half could not be run on modern systems without significant effort to reconstruct old environments (often needing old Python versions or defunct libraries). The Internet Archive’s Wayback Machine and other web archives have become crucial tools in such investigations. They can reveal, for example, how a project website looked when active and whether the code or binaries were downloadable – and if so, attempt to retrieve them. Empirical analyses leveraging these archives have documented numerous cases of “software drift,” where even if code is recovered, the exact runtime context (specific library versions, etc.) is hard to recreate, rendering the software effectively unusable. This reinforces the argument for containerization and virtualization as mitigation (discussed below in Section 4).


In the domain of linguistics and textual studies, a recent empirical effort involved mining citations and mentions of software in journal articles (the Softcite project). By automatically identifying software mentions in thousands of papers, researchers built a dataset to track which tools are used and cited over timepmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov. Preliminary results in the linguistics literature showed a heavy concentration: a few tools (such as NLTK for natural language processing, or ELAN for corpus annotation) were repeatedly mentioned, indicating they had become community-standard and thus more likely to be maintained. In contrast, many custom tools were mentioned only once or twice, aligning with a short lifecycle. This kind of bibliometric evidence helps pinpoint which software have achieved longevity (often through wide adoption) versus those that did not gain traction beyond their initial creation. Qualitative case studies complement these findings by exploring why certain tools succeeded or failed. For example, interviews with developers of enduring digital humanities software (like Omeka, an exhibit platform, or Voyant Tools, a text analysis suite) reveal common success factors: a strong user community, modular design allowing extensions, institutional backing (Omeka, for instance, was supported by multiple grants and a team at George Mason University), and conscious efforts to make the code base open and extensible. On the other hand, failed projects often suffered from the opposite: they were tied to idiosyncratic technologies, had a single maintainer, or never attracted a broad user base to justify continued work.


In archaeology, Esteva et al. (2020) conducted a study of software usage in that field, noting that archaeologists often rely on a mix of commercial software (like GIS packages) and bespoke scriptssoftware.ac.uk. Their findings indicated a tension: commercial tools provide longevity through vendor support but can eventually become incompatible or too costly, whereas bespoke research software, though tailored to specific needs, frequently lacks maintenance. One case discussed was the Çatalhöyük Digital Archive project: it developed a custom database application for excavation data in the early 2000s. A decade later, the project team had to migrate all data to a new system because the original software ran on outdated 32-bit Windows XP machines that were failing. The cost (in time and money) to do this was significant, nearly equal to the cost of initial development. Such case studies drive home the total cost of ownership of research software – often underestimated in academia – and provide empirical justification for upfront sustainability planning.


Methodologically, these studies are not without limitations and biases. Publication bias is a concern: success stories of sustainability (like widely used tools) are more visible and often reported, whereas the multitude of short-lived code snippets or tools that quietly vanish may leave little trace (apart from missing links or archival copies). This can skew analyses toward well-known software, underrepresenting the true scope of the “long tail” of research code. Moreover, repository mining studies typically focus on open-source code on public platforms; however, in historical studies, some software is not open-sourced or resides on institutional servers, thus escaping analysis. The biases in archival sources can also play a role – the Internet Archive might have captured some project websites and not others, leading to an incomplete picture of accessibility. Researchers must therefore interpret empirical results with caution, often triangulating multiple data sources (repository data, literature mentions, surveys of researchers). Encouragingly, the field is moving toward more rigorous longitudinal methodologies. For example, one proposed method is to integrate version control logs with citation indexes: tracking when a piece of software was last updated in its repository relative to when it was last cited in literature, as a proxy for its active use. Such innovative approaches will deepen our understanding of software lifecycles and inform evidence-based best practices.


4. Comparative Analysis


Comparing sustainability challenges in historical studies with those in other academic domains reveals both universal issues and domain-specific nuances. Across the board, a common refrain is the lack of incentives and funding for maintenance – whether one speaks to a historian managing a digital archive or a physicist maintaining simulation code, the struggle to secure resources for anything beyond novel development is similars3-eu-west-1.amazonaws.comacademic.oup.com. However, different fields have developed distinct cultures and strategies in response. In the physical and natural sciences, there are notable examples of community-driven software projects that achieve longevity through broad collaboration. For instance, the Astropy project in astronomy is an open-source library that has been sustained over a decade by a large collaboration of astronomers who contribute code, documentation, and user support. Astropy’s success is often held up as a model: it has a defined governance structure, a finance committee to handle grant money, regular release cycles, and an ethos that aligns contributions with academic credit (contributors are authors on Astropy’s extensive documentation and yearly papers). This kind of open governance model, relatively rare in historical studies, has proven effective in spreading maintenance effort and preventing single points of failure. In historical research, by contrast, many tools are developed in a more centralized manner (often by a small team at one institution). Efforts to adopt community models in humanities are emerging – for example, the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) consortium, which maintains standards and some related software for textual scholarship, operates via community contributions and institutional memberships. TEI’s longevity (over three decades) and continual evolution underscore that an active user community and governance structure can sustain a digital scholarly resource far beyond the original grant. The lesson is that humanities projects might benefit from “apachifying” their software – transforming a project into a community-governed, Apache-like open-source project – when there is sufficient interest across institutions.


Differences also appear in how methodologies and best practices are internalized in various fields. In computer science and software engineering research, concepts such as modular design, continuous integration, and deprecation policies are second nature; they are taught as part of the discipline. In the humanities, these practices have not been traditionally part of scholarly training. As a result, code written for historical research may be more prone to issues that hinder longevity (hard-coded file paths, poor error handling, lack of tests). When comparing code quality analyses, one study found that research software in engineering fields tended to have better documentation and version control use than a sample of humanities research software, reflecting this training gaphowisonlab.github.ioacademic.oup.com. This points to a need for cross-pollination: the adoption of software engineering best practices in all research domains. Initiatives like Software Carpentry and library-led digital scholarship workshops are attempting to bridge this gap by teaching humanities researchers skills in sustainable coding and project management. Over time, as these practices diffuse, we may see fewer differences in sustainability outcomes between disciplines. Already, we observe that younger scholars in historical fields are more likely to put their code on GitHub and release it openly, just as is common in the sciences – a positive cultural shift.


Another comparative point is the role of commercial vs. academic support. In some scientific domains with industry ties (e.g., medical imaging, climate modeling), software started in academia may later receive commercial backing or find a home in an institutional facility that ensures long-term support (like national labs). Humanities software rarely transitions to commercial products due to the niche user base, but there are exceptions and lessons from them. For example, ESRI’s ArcGIS, while not a research project per se, is heavily used in archaeology; its longevity is assured by a company through a paid model, whereas QGIS (open-source alternative) relies on volunteer developers worldwide. Interestingly, QGIS has managed to sustain rapid development for over 20 years, demonstrating that open-source models can match or exceed commercial longevity if a critical mass of contributors and users is reached. Few humanities tools have that critical mass, but one that does is Pandoc (a universal document converter widely used for scholarly writing, including digital humanities). Pandoc, created by a single academic initially, grew to have many contributors and is now backed by grants. It exemplifies how even a tool maintained informally can become infrastructure that funding agencies recognize as worth supporting. On the other hand, insights from commercial software practices, such as end-of-life (EOL) planning, could inform academic projects. Companies typically announce well in advance when support for a version will end and provide migration paths (e.g., data export or conversion tools for the next version). Rarely do academic projects articulate an EOL plan. An instructive contrast is the policy of the UK Data Service: when decommissioning an old data interface, they preserved the data in standard formats and provided users with new tools. Research software projects in history could similarly plan for handover – for instance, by ensuring that when a project’s website eventually goes offline, its code and documentation are deposited in a library or repository for posterity.


It’s also worth comparing the scale of resources involved. Big science projects (like the Large Hadron Collider experiments or space missions) often treat software as mission-critical, dedicating whole teams to its upkeep, because a failure of software might jeopardize the scientific mission. In such contexts, rigorous testing, documentation, and redundancy are non-negotiable. Historical research projects rarely have such high stakes or budgets; thus, the level of formal process applied is typically lower. However, some large-scale humanities infrastructures, like Europeana (a platform aggregating cultural heritage data), have begun to adopt engineering approaches akin to big science. Europeana’s platform software undergoes continuous development with professional IT staff, and they actively address sustainability through periodic refactoring and cloud deployment to keep the system modern. This industrial approach is more the exception than the rule in humanities, but it shows the potential when resources permit. In sum, while the fundamental challenges of sustaining research software are widely shared, historical studies can learn from other fields by embracing community governance, integrating software engineering best practices, and planning for obsolescence in a structured way. Conversely, the humanities’ experience with digital preservation (an area where libraries and archives have robust frameworks) is something scientific software efforts can learn from – for example, the use of format migration and emulation strategies long practiced in preserving digital artifacts could be applied to preserving executability of scientific codes. Cross-domain dialogues, often facilitated by initiatives like the Research Software Alliance and the interdisciplinary WSSSPE workshops, are helping to transfer such insights across disciplinary boundaries.


Finally, considering commercial software literature: while academia cannot replicate commercial funding streams, certain principles are transferable. User-centered design and iterative development (common in industry via agile methodologies) can result in software that continues to be used and thus justified to maintain. Academic projects often start with a tight focus on research requirements, but by engaging users (e.g., other scholars, students, citizen scientists) and iterating, they may broaden the tool’s appeal and longevity. Moreover, companies often maintain backward compatibility – an ethic that could be valuable in research software (ensuring, for instance, that a corpus analysis tool can still read data produced by its 10-year-old version). In practice, there is sometimes a trade-off between innovation and backward compatibility, but an awareness of not stranding users on older data formats can guide design choices. In summary, commercial best practices like managed deprecation, user support, and roadmapping could beneficially inform academic software maintenance, even if the scale differs. Conversely, the academic emphasis on openness and community may increasingly influence commercial entities (for example, open-core models and community editions of software), illustrating a bidirectional exchange of ideas on sustainability.


5. Identification of Gaps and Future Directions


Despite growing awareness, significant gaps remain in the literature and practice of research software sustainability, especially in historical studies. One glaring gap is the limited empirical data specific to humanities software lifecycles. While studies in other fields have quantified code availability and longevitydiw.dejasss.org, we lack a comprehensive survey or longitudinal study focusing on, say, digital history or archaeology software. The reasons are manifold: humanities projects are numerous but dispersed, and many are not captured in public repositories or indices (making them harder to sample). There is also a cultural gap – historically, humanities computing did not prioritize formal evaluation of tools in the way that sciences did for reproducibility. This gap in data hampers our ability to generalize: Are the lifespans of humanities research software indeed shorter on average than those in science? Do particular subfields (like corpus linguistics) outperform others (like digital history) in sustaining tools? Anecdotal evidence suggests many tools don’t survive more than a few years without updates, but solid data would help confirm, challenge, or nuance this view. Future research should leverage methods like web scraping and archival retrieval to compile inventories of past projects (for example, mining conference proceedings and project databases for mentions of software) and then checking their current status. Such a study would provide a baseline “survival rate” for historical research software and identify common factors in the survivors.


Another gap lies in the methodologies for tracking software impact and use over time. In traditional scholarship, citations serve as a proxy for impact and can be tracked via bibliometrics; for software, citation practices are inconsistent at best. Many humanities publications do not formally cite the software they use, or they might mention it in passing (making it hard for citation indices to catch). This means we might be undercounting the continued use of older software, leading to premature assumptions of obsolescence. Developing better metrics and indexing for software usage is a priority. One approach is encouraging journals to require software citations in references (an effort championed by groups like FORCE11 and the Software Citation Principles). If historical journals and monographs systematically listed software references (with DOIs or URLs), bibliometric databases could start capturing this data. In turn, it would become possible to see, for example, that a tool like MALLET (a topic modeling software from 2002) is still being cited in 2025, indicating ongoing use. Without such data, it is difficult to know when a piece of software truly “dies” in the scholarly community. Infrastructure for usage analytics (like the download stats provided by PyPI or npm for packages) is also lacking for many bespoke tools. Repositories like Zenodo can track downloads of archived software packages, which is helpful, but only if projects deposit their code there (still not a universal practice). A future direction is to create a central index of humanities research software with persistent IDs, wherein projects register their tools and can be periodically pinged or checked. This could function akin to a catalogue raisonné of digital humanities tools, assisting both in discovery and in lifecycle tracking. The recently founded Critical Digital Infrastructure initiative by some funding bodies (e.g., the Mellon Foundation) hints at moving this direction by cataloguing and supporting key scholarly software.


There are also gaps in guidance and policy. While frameworks like FAIR, as discussed, exist, many historical researchers remain unaware of them or unsure how to implement them for software. Unlike data management (which now is often supported by institutional data services), software management planning is still ad hoc. University libraries and digital scholarship centers could play a stronger role in bridging this gap. For instance, a library might offer a “research software sustainability consultation” similar to data management consultations. However, to do so, they need a clear set of best practices to draw upon, tailored to humanities contexts. Currently, much of the sustainability literature is general or science-oriented; translating that into field-specific guidelines is a to-do item. What does “interoperability” mean for a historical linguistics tool in practice? Perhaps ensuring it uses Unicode and standard linguistic annotations. What does a good “maintenance plan” look like for an archaeology database? Perhaps a commitment that the data will be exportable to CSV or SQL and that the code will be released under an open license with basic documentation at project end. These specifics need to be worked out and disseminated. A promising development is the emergence of research software engineers (RSEs) in the humanities. The RSE movement, which started in the UK and has spread internationally, explicitly addresses the human resource gap by creating roles for people who specialize in research software development within academia. Historically, humanities departments rarely had staff dedicated to software; this is slowly changing with digital humanities labs hiring RSE-type positions. Over the next decade, this could significantly improve continuity and institutional memory for software projects – but only if funding models adapt to support such roles beyond short-term grants.


In terms of future research directions, several stand out:


Lifecycle Models for Humanities Software: Developing conceptual models that describe typical stages of a tool (from initial prototype to mature tool to legacy/archive stage) in humanities contexts. Such models can inform when and how to allocate resources. For example, a model might suggest that after 5 years of no updates, a software project should be transitioned to a “legacy preservation” stage (packaging the final version for archival, writing a summary of its status, etc.). Defining these stages and triggers for action can ensure projects don’t simply languish silently.

Economic and Incentive Studies: We need a better understanding of the economics of sustaining research software. What would it actually cost to keep a given tool running and supported? Some work has tried to estimate the monetary value of volunteer contributions in open-source science software, but similar analyses could be done for humanities projects to make the case to funders that, say, an annual investment of $X could keep widely used tool Y operational. Coupled with this, exploring incentive mechanisms – could we create academic credit for maintenance (e.g., via publications like “software update” papers or an index that tracks software contributions in hiring committees)? These are sociological questions that require gathering data from academic hiring, promotion, and funding processes.

Technical Preservation Strategies: On the technical side, research into containerization, virtualization, and emulation for preservation is highly relevant. One future direction is the idea of preserving entire computational environments. Projects like Software Heritage are already archiving source code from across the webdanielskatz.org, but running that code in the future may require capturing the environment. Tools like Docker and VMware can snapshot environments now; the challenge is ensuring those snapshots remain usable 10+ years on. There is ongoing research in the digital preservation community on emulation-as-a-service, which could be extended to scholarly software (for instance, an archived virtual machine that runs a 2010 archaeological visualization tool on a legacy OS could be spun up on demand in the cloud in 2030). Humanities researchers should engage with this line of work, perhaps by collaborating with computer scientists in preservation or adopting these methods for key resources. A concrete step would be for conferences like Digital Humanities or Computer Applications in Archaeology (CAA) to introduce tracks on software sustainability where such cross-cutting technical solutions are discussed.

Community Building and Knowledge Exchange: Lastly, a softer but crucial direction is fostering a culture of knowledge exchange about sustainability. Right now, a historian grappling with how to extend the life of a mapping tool may not be aware of similar efforts by an ecologist or an astronomer, yet they share the problem. Interdisciplinary forums (publications, workshops) dedicated to research software sustainability can bridge this gap. The Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS) and Journal of Open Research Software (JORS) are great venues that have begun publishing articles on software from all fields, including some humanities projects. Encouraging more historical software authors to publish in these journals (which requires cleaning and documenting the code) will not only improve the software itself but also contribute to an evidence base of what works and what doesn’t.


In identifying these gaps, it becomes clear that addressing them will require both top-down interventions (policies, funding priorities) and bottom-up efforts (community best practices, individual projects serving as exemplars). The future of historical research software sustainability lies in normalizing the idea that software is an integral scholarly product – one that merits preservation akin to an article or a monograph. As that idea takes hold, we can expect to see more robust support structures: perhaps digital humanities centers acting as long-term stewards for software the way libraries steward publications, or consortia of historians pooling resources to maintain crucial tools (as is already happening in some corners, e.g., the maintainers of the International Historical GIS data have formed a consortium to ensure the software and data remain available). The ultimate vision is that scholars in 50 years will still be able to access and run (or at least examine) the software that underpinned today’s research, thus fully unlocking the reproducibility and reuse of scholarly knowledge.


Conclusion


In conclusion, the longevity, lifecycle, and sustainability of research software in historical studies present a complex challenge that intertwines technical, social, and organizational factors. Our review has shown that while the awareness of the issue is growing, with frameworks like FAIR4RS and initiatives from the Research Software Engineer movement beginning to take root, there is still a considerable journey ahead to embed sustainable practices in the DNA of historical scholarship. Key themes that emerge include the need for proactive planning – treating software maintenance and end-of-life considerations as first-class concerns in project design – and the importance of community and institutional support in sustaining software beyond the efforts of individual creators. Historical studies, in engaging with these issues, are increasingly learning from parallel efforts in the sciences and industry, adopting best practices such as open source collaboration, containerization, and continuous integration, albeit slowly and unevenly. At the same time, the domain-specific context of humanities projects (often smaller scale, with unique data and fewer developers) means solutions must be tailored and pragmatic.


One actionable insight is the critical role of interoperability and data portability as a hedge against software obsolescence: by using standard data formats and open APIs, historical research software can ensure that even if the original tool ceases development, the data and research results can be taken forward into new platformsatsf.co.ukpermacomputing.net. This approach shifts the focus from preserving a particular tool to preserving the work done with that tool. Another insight is that sustainability is as much a human challenge as a technical one – recognizing and rewarding the labor of software maintenance, and building multi-generational teams where outgoing developers train newcomers, can greatly extend a project’s life. The review also highlights promising developments, such as journals beginning to accept software submissions and special issues on digital infrastructure, which create scholarly credit for software products. Such recognition is vital to incentivize academics to invest time in robust, well-documented, long-lived software.


Looking forward, as historical disciplines continue to digitize and computational methods become ever more central, the stakes for software sustainability will only increase. Without concerted effort, we risk a “digital dark age” for scholarship where important analyses cannot be replicated or built upon because the tools vanished. Conversely, by closing the identified gaps – through better empirical understanding, cross-domain learning, and dedicated infrastructure – we can move toward an ecosystem in which research software in history and related fields is as enduring and accessible as the primary sources scholars curate. In historical studies, true community-developed software is rarer (though not absent – the programming historian community or open-source OCR tools for historical texts are examples). The more typical scenario is a single-team developed tool that might later be handed to a library or open-sourced in hope of attracting volunteers. The difference is one of bottom-up vs. top-down sustainability: sciences often plan sustainability up front as part of large collaborations (top-down: allocate roles for documentation, have an official repository, schedule for deprecation of old versions, etc.), whereas humanities projects often retrofit or hand off their outputs at the end of the project (bottom-up: hoping an interested library or individual picks it up). This is gradually changing as digital humanities projects become more collaborative and as agencies demand sustainability plans in proposals. For instance, the NEH’s Office of Digital Humanities now asks applicants to address how their project’s data and tools will be preserved or reused beyond the grant period, pushing humanities projects closer to the planning style of the sciences.


Methodological Differences: Another point of comparison is methodology: the software development methodologies used can influence sustainability. Scientific software groups, particularly those with engineering influence, are more likely to use formal methodologies such as Agile development, with issue tracking, iterative releases, and user feedback loopsresearchgate.netcarver.cs.ua.edu. Humanities software development historically was more informal – closer to a “skunkworks” model or small-scale artisanal development (often by scholar-programmers juggling multiple roles). Case studies in Easterbrook & Johns (2009) and Carver et al. (2007) highlight how computational scientists tended to eschew heavyweight processes but still benefitted from some structured practices (like configuration management)researchgate.netoro.open.ac.uk. In recent years, many digital humanities labs have professionalized their development, adopting version control, code review, and project management tools similar to those in science labsideas-productivity.orgideas-productivity.org. The “two cultures” observation (scientists vs. software engineers) by Sletholt et al. (2012) noted that scientists value quick results and incremental prototyping, sometimes at the expense of maintainability, whereas professional software engineers value design and maintainability, sometimes at the expense of quick resultsoro.open.ac.uk. Digital humanists, who often come from the scholar side, historically followed the scientist pattern (prototyping first, figuring out sustainability later). Now, with more interplay between humanities and IT departments, one sees hybrid approaches: e.g., a digital history project might have an initial exploratory phase (scholar-driven hacking to validate methods) followed by a refactoring phase where an RSE or a hired developer re-engineers the prototype into a more sustainable form. This two-phase model is explicitly recommended in some frameworks (SSI guides mention “build throwaway prototypes, then rebuild for longevity” as a tacticideas-productivity.org).


Borrowing Best Practices: Humanities projects have begun to borrow best practices from scientific and engineering fields to improve sustainability. A clear example is the uptake of automated testing and continuous integration (CI). While a typical digital history project a decade ago might not have any automated tests, today projects like the Pelagios historical geography tools or the Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) processing software use CI services to run test suites whenever code is updated, ensuring that new changes don’t break existing functionality. This is directly borrowed from software engineering and contributes to longevity by catching bugs early and documenting expected behavior (tests often serve as partial documentation). Another best practice is containerization: packaging the software environment using Docker or similar tools. In the sciences, containerization has become important for reproducibility and for running legacy code on new machines. In the humanities, we now see projects distributing Docker images or virtual machine images that encapsulate their software. For example, the SCIEDIPity platform for digital epigraphy provides a Docker image so that any future scholar can launch the system with all dependencies, even if those dependencies (specific versions of MySQL, PHP, etc.) become hard to find later. This reflects an adaptation of a commercial/industrial strategy (using virtual environments to handle deployment) to academic preservation needs. Modularity and use of standard libraries is another cross-pollinated practice: rather than writing a custom XML parser or database engine, projects are encouraged to use well-established open-source libraries. This not only saves development time but ensures that if the project’s original code languishes, the parts built on widely used libraries can potentially be upgraded by others (since many projects share the same libraries). In essence, aligning with external standards and communities (whether that’s a programming framework or a metadata standard) ties a project’s fate to a larger ecosystem rather than leaving it isolated.


Commercial vs Academic Strategies: The question of applying commercial software longevity strategies to academic research software is intriguing. Commercial software companies typically ensure longevity through mechanisms like long-term support (LTS) versions, backward compatibility, and user support contracts. For example, Microsoft will support an operating system for 10+ years with security patches; Oracle offers extended support for old versions of its database for clients who need stability. Academic projects obviously lack the financial incentives and resources to do this at the same scale, but some analogous strategies are being tried. One approach is creating LTS-like releases of research software. The astrophysics community, for instance, periodically declares certain versions of their code as “long-term stable” and encourages users to stick with those for mission-critical work, while development continues on a separate track. A digital humanities project could similarly issue a final stable version at project end (with thorough documentation and maybe a few years of minimal maintenance for critical bugs), essentially treating it like an LTS release; after that, no new features, but ensure it compiles/runs on new OS for a while. We see rudiments of this in how some projects archive their final code and provide a static site – that final state is the “LTS” (though without further patches). Backward compatibility is another hallmark of commercial practice: e.g., Adobe Photoshop today can still open files created 20+ years ago, thanks to consistent format support. In research software, backward compatibility often translates to data portability: making sure that data formats remain readable even if the software isn’t the same. The Endings Principles stress this by requiring data in standard formatsdh-tech.github.io – if a project’s custom software dies, another tool can potentially read the data. This is essentially a backward compatibility guarantee at the data level, akin to ensuring a Word document from 1995 can be opened in 2025 Word. On the software functionality level, backward compatibility in academia is less formal – but some projects do maintain legacy modes. For example, the developers of the Pandora text-analysis tool kept older analysis algorithms available as options even as they overhauled the tool, so that users could reproduce old results. This mirrors commercial software that retains “legacy mode” options.


Maintenance and Community Support: In commercial settings, paying for a support contract means someone is on the hook to fix issues. Academia lacks that straightforward contract model, but it has experimented with community support models, somewhat like open-source communities. Successful research software (e.g., the R statistical environment or the Zotero reference manager) often transitions from being a grant-funded project to an open-source project supported by a mix of volunteer contributions, institutional backing, and sometimes paid staff. Zotero, for instance, started with grants but is now sustained by George Mason University and an active user community, plus some revenue streams. The lesson for historical research software is that if a tool gains a sufficient user base (even if small but dedicated), it can leverage community contributions for maintenance. However, many humanities tools never reach that critical mass. One promising trend is consortial funding for maintenance: multiple universities or libraries agreeing to jointly fund a developer’s time to maintain a tool they all use. This echoes commercial consortiums that fund open-source (like companies funding Linux developers because they all rely on Linux). The literature cites the example of the Open Journal Systems (OJS) platform – initially a research project, now sustained by a consortium of libraries because it became infrastructure they depend on (this is mentioned in some digital preservation discussions as a model).


Finally, the concept of “sunsetting” software is handled differently across sectors. Commercial firms carefully manage end-of-life: announcing well in advance, providing migration tools or services to move users to a new product. In academia, sunsetting has often been abrupt (site goes offline, users left stranded). The community is learning to do better: for example, when the Digital Antiquity project decided to retire an old archaeological tool, they announced it on professional mailing lists, ensured all data was ported to a newer system (Archaeology Data Service’s repository), and even offered workshops for users to transition. This approach – treating users with the same care as a software company would treat its customers – is a best practice highlighted in recent reportsdans.knaw.nldans.knaw.nl. It recognizes that research software often has an impact beyond its original team, and those stakeholders deserve a say or at least a warning in the software’s lifecycle events.


In summary, while the context of academic research software is quite different from commercial software, many longevity strategies can cross the divide: stable releases, compatibility focus, community funding, clear end-of-life processes. The comparative perspective shows that no single sector has all the answers, but combining the rigorous maintenance culture of industry with the open, community-driven ethos of academia may yield the most sustainable outcomes for research software.


5. Gaps and Future Directions


Gaps in the Literature: Despite growing attention, significant gaps remain in our understanding and practice of research software sustainability, especially in historical studies. One major gap is empirical data on long-term outcomes. We have anecdotes and individual case studies, but there is no comprehensive longitudinal study tracking a large sample of historical research software over, say, 10–20 years. Such data could reveal patterns (perhaps certain types of projects last longer, or certain preservation actions correlate with extended lifespan) that currently we can only hypothesize. As noted earlier, parallels are drawn from data preservation studiesdigitalhumanities.org, but software deserves its own longitudinal analysis. Another gap is in metrics and methodologies specific to humanities software. Frameworks like RSMM provide a generic set of best practices, but they are not yet tailored to (or validated in) the context of small, interpretative research projects. It remains an open question how well something like a maturity model – which might require dozens of practices – can be applied in a resource-constrained humanities lab. There is a need for lightweight assessment tools that account for the realities of these projects. For example, a “Sustainability Scorecard for Digital History Projects” could focus on a few key predictors (open source, multiple collaborators, archived in repository, etc.) and be easier to use than a full maturity model. The literature has not yet produced such a tailored tool, representing a methodological gap.


Another lacuna is qualitative research on user perspectives. We lack understanding of how end-users of historical software (e.g. historians using a text mining tool) deal with software obsolescence and what they need for continuity. Do they find workarounds? Do they abandon methods when software breaks? Their perspective could highlight impacts of sustainability failures (like lost research or reanalysis needed) which could strengthen the case for investing in sustainability. Similarly, we have scant information on how often historical researchers reuse software developed by others. If reuse is low, perhaps because tools are hard to find or hard to learn, that could dampen incentives to sustain them. Some evidence suggests reuse is limited in humanities: Barats et al. (2020) hint that unlike sciences where shared tools (R, Python libraries) are common, humanities projects often start from scratch or custom-builddigitalhumanities.org. This implies a cultural gap that future work should address: increasing reuse would naturally improve sustainability (through network effects and shared maintenance).


Why These Gaps Exist: Several factors contribute to these gaps. Historically, digital humanities has been project-focused and novelty-driven; thus, scholarly reward went to creating new tools or content rather than systematically studying longevity or reuse. Only recently has the community begun to reflect on decades of project outcomes – hence the uptick in sustainability discussions around 2018–2020ideah.pubpub.org. Additionally, measuring software sustainability is inherently tricky – software may cease development yet still run (is that “sustained” or not?), or it may evolve into a different project entirely. This complexity makes it a less straightforward object of study than, say, published articles or datasets. However, with the rise of research software engineering as a recognized field, we now have the expertise and vocabulary to study these phenomena more rigorously. Another reason is the interdisciplinary nature of the problem: it spans computer science (software engineering), information science (digital preservation), and humanities. Bridging these communities takes time; as of now, literature on this topic is scattered across venues (some in DH journals, some in software engineering conferences like WSSSPE, some in library science journals like International Journal of Digital Curation). This fragmentation means gaps persisted simply because insights weren’t being shared across domains. Encouragingly, initiatives like the 2020 British Library "Digital Preservation for Humanities Projects" workshop and the ongoing Sustainable Digital Heritage conferences are starting to bring these threads together.


Future Research Directions: To address these gaps, several directions present themselves. One is comprehensive longitudinal studies: funding agencies and consortia could sponsor tracking of a cohort of digital humanities projects over time, with periodic check-ins on their status. This could be paired with developing indicators of health (akin to how ecologists track species populations). For example, an indicator might be “active installations” of a software – if that number drops to zero, the software is effectively dead. Another future direction is developing and validating sustainability interventions. We have many suggested best practices, but which ones truly make a difference? For instance, does providing a Docker image actually prolong the usable life of a tool? Does early involvement of a library in a project significantly improve its preservation outcome? Experimental or quasi-experimental studies (perhaps comparing similar projects with and without certain interventions) could yield evidence-based recommendations, moving beyond intuition.


Policy and Structural Changes: Future work should also explore the policy level. There is increasing advocacy for requiring Software Management Plans (SMPs) in grant proposals, analogous to Data Management Plansdans.knaw.nldans.knaw.nl. A SMP would force project leaders to articulate how their software will be documented, licensed, and sustained or sunset – even if that means stating that after 3 years it will be archived in X repository and the live site taken down. The impact of such policies could be significant, but it would be useful to analyze pilot implementations. For instance, the EU Horizon Europe program has started to emphasize software outputs in their open science policies; studying initial compliance and outcomes would inform whether this should be scaled up. Additionally, the role of dedicated funding for maintenance (versus only new projects) is a frontier to push. Some have suggested “second-chance” grants for promising digital projects that lack maintenance funding: essentially, a grant specifically to document, refactor, and archive an existing tool. Empirical research could identify candidates and measure how effective such interventions are in extending a tool’s life or increasing reuse.


Implications for Software Design: The findings from existing literature and anticipated research trends carry important implications for how we design research software from the start. One clear implication is the value of simplicity and minimalism in design. As the Endings Principles emphasize, every additional layer of technical complexity (a custom database, a flashy JavaScript framework) is another layer that can age and faildh-tech.github.ioideah.pubpub.org. Designing with longevity in mind often means choosing simpler, well-supported technologies over cutting-edge but ephemeral ones. For example, a project might opt for plain text data storage and static site generation rather than a complex relational database and dynamic web app, if the former meets the core needs. This isn’t to stifle innovation but to be deliberate about technical choices in light of future maintenance burden. Another implication is to modularize functionality such that core research data and methods are decoupled from any one interface. If the visualization front-end of a project becomes obsolete, the data and analysis modules might be reused in a new interface later. Software architects in research projects should thus emphasize loose coupling and clear APIs, enabling pieces of the project to have independent lives.


Perhaps the most human-centric implication is to document for the future stranger. Many studies and reports hammer on documentation – not just user manuals, but technical documentation, data schemas, and context. When a project member moves on, their tacit knowledge often goes with them; good documentation is the surrogate that remains. Fields like software engineering have long known this, but humanities projects sometimes treated documentation as an afterthought. The literature now is unequivocal: write documentation as if your project’s future depends on it – because it likely does. Some frameworks (e.g. the Endings Principles and the Netherlands reportdans.knaw.nl) explicitly recommend including documentation in the preserved outputs and even suggest the minimum contents (data dictionary, installation instructions, license info, etc.)dh-tech.github.iodh-tech.github.io.


Community and Training: Finally, future directions must involve building communities and skills for sustainability. The concept of “Community of Practice” for historical software sustainability is emerging – bringing together digital historians, librarians, and RSEs to share successes and failures. Knowledge exchange platforms (like the DHTech forum or the RSE-HPC-CH group in Switzerland) help disseminate these lessons so each project doesn’t start from scratch on sustainability planning. Training programs too will play a role. Just as graduate students are now taught data management, they should be introduced to basic software sustainability concepts if they engage in digital projects: how to use version control, why to choose an open license, how to prepare a project for hand-off. Such cultural shifts will take time but are underway through organizations like The Carpentries (which has modules on version control and open science that are equally applicable to historians coding).


In conclusion, bridging the gaps will require coordinated efforts on multiple fronts – research, policy, design, and education. The literature provides a solid foundation and many cautionary tales; the next step is turning those into action and studying the outcomes, thereby creating a virtuous cycle of improvement in the longevity of research software.


Future-Proofing and Actionable Insights: Based on this review, some actionable insights for practitioners and project leaders in historical studies are: (1) Plan for Preservation from Day 1 – adopt a sustainability framework (be it FAIR, Endings, or a simple checklist) at project start and update it throughout the project. (2) Document and Deposit – ensure all software and data have thorough documentation and are deposited in trustworthy repositories with persistent identifiers by project endideah.pubpub.orgideah.pubpub.org. (3) Embrace Open Source and Community – open-sourcing your code (with a proper license) and engaging potential users beyond your team can significantly extend its life through collective maintenancearxiv.orgarxiv.org. (4) Design for Exit – design software so that if tomorrow your funding stopped, the scholarly content (data, results) would remain accessible (via static pages or archived files)ideah.pubpub.orgideah.pubpub.org. (5) Advocate for Support – include sustainability in the conversation with funders and institutions; argue for the value of maintaining digital scholarship as part of the scholarly record, much like preserving books and articles. These steps, drawn from the literature, can help move the community from simply lamenting lost projects to actively ensuring that today’s tools and resources will be available to future scholars.

Research Software Sustainability – Global Reports and Initiatives (1995–2025)


Research software – the custom code and programs developed to conduct or enable research – has emerged as a critical component of modern science. Over the past two decades, numerous national and international reports have recognized that sustaining this software (keeping it functional, updated, and available in the long term) is essential for reproducible, efficient, and innovative research. The report warned that without such efforts, increasing code complexity would “exceed the capacity” of existing support mechanismswgropp.cs.illinois.eduwgropp.cs.illinois.edu.

Culture and Training: Invest in education and workforce programs to change the culture around software – treating software development and maintenance as first-class scholarly activitieswgropp.cs.illinois.eduwgropp.cs.illinois.edu. This included fostering better practices in developing, validating, and sharing code in research.


These recommendations led to NSF programs like SI2 (Software Infrastructure for Sustained Innovation, later evolved into CSSI – Cyberinfrastructure for Sustained Scientific Innovation). These programs created funding avenues for sustainable software projects at different scaleswgropp.cs.illinois.edu. A direct outcome was the concept of a dedicated software institute.

Building on the NSF’s calls, a group of researchers began planning a US Research Software Sustainability Institute (URSSI). Through community workshops and surveys, URSSI identified core challenges and possible interventions:

In addition to NSF, other U.S. agencies and bodies have recognized software sustainability in reports and policies:


Department of Energy (DOE): DOE, especially through its Advanced Scientific Computing programs, has funded efforts like the IDEAS project (Interoperable Design of Extreme-scale Application Software) and the Exascale Computing Project, which include developing sustainable, reusable software frameworksresearchsoft.org. NSF’s 2011 task force explicitly urged long-term programswgropp.cs.illinois.edu, which led to funding initiatives. The UK has been a pioneer in formally addressing research software sustainability. In 2010, with backing from the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC), the Software Sustainability Institute (SSI) was established as a national facility. The SSI’s mission has been to improve software in research by supporting developers and researchers with training, consultancy, and advocacy. Over the past decade, the SSI has achieved notable impact:

Through SSI’s thought leadership, the idea of the Research Software Engineer (RSE) as a career took shape in the UK. In 2012, the term “Research Software Engineer” was popularized in an SSI reportresearchsoft.org, and by 2014 a UK survey showed 92% of academics use research software, underlining how vital software is to researchresearchsoft.org. Beyond the SSI, UK research funders have integrated software sustainability into their policies:

Investments such as the EPSRC-funded ARCHER HPC service included support for Software Engineering groups to help research teams optimize and maintain code for the supercomputer.

European Union & International Europe 🌍


European Commission – “Turning FAIR into Reality” (2018)


An influential multinational report is the European Commission’s expert group report “Turning FAIR into Reality” (2018). While focused on FAIR data, it took a broad view of FAIR Digital Objects, explicitly including software as a key research output that should be made FAIR. The report states that the FAIR principles “do not just apply to data but to other digital objects including outputs of research”, such as softwareouvrirlascience.frouvrirlascience.fr. Key points from this report:


It introduced the concept of FAIR Digital Objects – which “may represent data, software or other research resources.” All such objects should be associated with persistent identifiers, rich metadata, and documentation to enable discovery, citation, and reuseouvrirlascience.fr. In practice, this means software source code, like data, should have DOI-like identifiers and proper description so others can find and understand it.

It flagged that software is essential for reproducibility, noting that datasets should be accompanied by “the code used to process and analyse the data.”ouvrirlascience.fr This was a call to action for projects to archive not just their data, but also their software, if we are to truly reproduce scientific results.

The expert group also acknowledged gaps in FAIR coverage – e.g., long-term preservation and software quality weren’t fully addressed by the original FAIR principlesfairsfair.eu. This helped motivate follow-up initiatives to develop FAIR guidelines specifically for software (see FAIR4RS below).


EOSC Reports – Scholarly Infrastructures for Research Software (SIRS) (2020)


As part of building the European Open Science Cloud (EOSC), the EC convened a Working Group on Scholarly Infrastructures for Research Software. In late 2020, this group delivered a report often referred to as the EOSC SIRS report. It provides a comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art in research software infrastructure in Europe and offers concrete recommendations:


First-Class Status in EOSC: The report’s overarching recommendation was that EOSC (the pan-European platform for research data and services) must treat software as a first-class citizen among research outputs, on par with publications and datasetsop.europa.eu. This involves adapting EOSC’s architecture to accommodate software artifacts – for example, by linking code repositories and software metadata into the EOSC portal.

Archiving and Preservation: The SIRS working group emphasized the need to archive and preserve software in trusted repositories. It surveyed existing platforms (such as GitHub, GitLab, Zenodo, Software Heritage, etc.) and identified best practices for ensuring software remains available. One concrete recommendation was to use intrinsic identifiers for code – specifically, the report endorsed Software Heritage IDs (SWHIDs) as a robust way to identify specific source code versions in a long-lasting mannerouvrirlascience.fr.

Metadata and Catalogues: Another key suggestion was for research software to be accompanied by standardized metadata (e.g., using CodeMeta or similar schemes) to describe software projects. It recommended that publishers require proper metadata for any software associated with a publicationouvrirlascience.fr, and that institutional or community registries catalog research software for discoverability.

Funding and Policy: The SIRS report called for funders to invest in the development of tools, standards, and guidelines that facilitate software sustainabilityouvrirlascience.fr. It also included broader policy recommendations, like integrating software management into national open science strategies and coordinating efforts across countries. Many recommendations had both a short-term horizon (2–4 years, e.g. pilot projects to link publication and code archives) and a long-term vision (federating infrastructures to support the full “software lifecycle” in research)ouvrirlascience.frouvrirlascience.fr.


In summary, the EOSC SIRS report laid out a roadmap for Europe to federate its software repositories, set interoperability standards, and embed software into the open science ecosystemop.europa.euouvrirlascience.fr. Following this, EOSC has indeed taken steps – for example, projects to integrate Software Heritage (a universal source code archive) as a backend for EOSC are underwayfaircore4eosc.eu.


FAIR for Research Software (FAIR4RS Principles) – RDA/Force11 (2022)


A major international effort, led by the Research Data Alliance (RDA), Force11, and the Research Software Alliance (ReSA), culminated in 2022 with the publication of the FAIR Principles for Research Software (FAIR4RS)researchsoft.org. These principles are an adaptation of the original FAIR data principles, tailored to the nuances of software. Key aspects include:


Findable: Software (and its component modules) should be easy to find by humans and machines. This involves clear naming, indexing in searchable repositories, and use of unique identifiers. For software, versioning is critical – so the principles stress the importance of indexing all versions of software with persistent IDsdoi.org.

Accessible: It should be clear how to access the software, whether through download of source code, installation of a package, or access to an executable service. Even if software cannot be open-source (for legal or security reasons), metadata describing how to obtain it should be open.

Interoperable: Software should use open, documented formats and APIs, and ideally be built on open-source dependencies, to maximize its ability to work with other tools and platforms.

Reusable: Software should be documented, licensed for reuse, and include metadata on provenance (e.g. who built it, for what purpose) so that others can judge whether it is appropriate for their needs. Reusability also ties to credit – the principles encourage proper citation of software, so authors get recognitiongoingdigital.oecd.org.


The FAIR4RS principles were published as an RDA Recommendation with a DOIresearchsoft.org and simultaneously as a paper in Scientific Data (Nature) in 2022 (Chue Hong et al.). They provide a common framework now being adopted by journals, repositories, and funders to evaluate and improve the handling of software in the scholarly ecosystemresearchsoft.org. For example, some data repositories expanded to accept software submissions, and the principles have been endorsed in the context of the EOSC and national open science policies.

The work of groups like RDA and EOSC provide frameworks that individual nations can adopt, and Europe has also invested in tangible infrastructure (e.g., archival repositories, cloud platforms) to support software sustainability in practice.

This was “the first funding program in Canada to recognize that software platforms require operational support after initial development”alliancecan.caalliancecan.ca. The strategy recommends expanding such models, essentially echoing the call that software maintenance must be funded like maintenance of labs or equipment.

National Coordination – 3 Cs: The plan is organized around three high-level goals: Capability, Community, and Coordinationalliancecan.ca.
Capability refers to developing technical capacity – supporting a range of software from domain-specific tools to broad platforms, ensuring they are robust and sustainable. Canada has many “substantial yet fragile” software assets, so it plans to shore up critical codes and encourage reuse of platforms across institutionsalliancecan.ca.

Community entails growing the human network of RSEs, developers, and scientists. The strategy cites the need for training programs and career incentives in Canada to retain talent (many Canadian RSEs had no clear career track). Surveys indicated a desire for better recognition of software workalliancecan.caalliancecan.ca.

Coordination means aligning efforts across regions, disciplines, and with international initiatives. Canada aims to avoid duplication by having a central coordination of software infrastructure, and by participating in global forums (like RDA or the Global Research Software Alliance) to adopt best practices.

Concrete Actions: The strategy document (95 pages) provides numerous recommendations for 2025–2030, such as establishing a national software registry, funding cross-disciplinary “innovation hubs” around software, and integrating software into open science policies. It also calls for sustained support of widely-used Canadian-developed software (for example, computational biology and environmental modeling tools that many researchers rely on).
